headline: Bank earnings, retail sales, SCOTUS tariff ruling: What to Watch
summary: Market Domination Overtime Host Josh Lipton previews several of the biggest stories to come tomorrow, Wednesday, January 14, including earnings results from major banks Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC), and Bank of America (BAC); the latest print on US retail sales data from November; and the US Supreme Court's (SCOTUS) expected ruling on President Trump's tariff policies. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

headline: JPMorgan Stock Rises After Sharp Drop on Earnings. What Spooked Markets.
summary: JPMorgan Chase  stock was showing signs of recovery in Wednesday’s premarket following a sharp fall the previous session on disappointing fourth-quarter results.  While the bank’s adjusted earnings beat analysts’ estimates, profits fell 7% from a year earlier on the back of lower-than-expected investment banking fees.  The banking giant had to set up a $2.2 billion credit reserve as part of agreeing to buy the iPhone maker’s card portfolio.

content.title: JPMorgan Stock Rises After Sharp Drop on Earnings. What Spooked Markets.
content.summary: JPMorgan Chase  stock was showing signs of recovery in Wednesday’s premarket following a sharp fall the previous session on disappointing fourth-quarter results.  While the bank’s adjusted earnings beat analysts’ estimates, profits fell 7% from a year earlier on the back of lower-than-expected investment banking fees.  The banking giant had to set up a $2.2 billion credit reserve as part of agreeing to buy the iPhone maker’s card portfolio.

headline: Bank earnings: What else to expect as JPMorgan comes under pressure
summary: While JPMorgan Chase (JPM) kicks off earnings season for Big Banks this week, HSBC Head of US Financials Research Saul Martinez talks about his earnings forecast for other banking institutions this week. Also watch Saul Martinez discuss JPMorgan's latest earnings release and what President Trump's proposed 10% cap on credit card rates could mean for credit lenders. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

headline: Wells Fargo Profit Hit by Severance as Staff Cut by 5,600
summary: Expenses were $13.7 billion, compared with the $13.6 billion predicted by analysts in a Bloomberg survey, according to a statement Wednesday.  “We have built a strong foundation and have made great progress in improving growth and returns, though we have operated with significant constraints,” Chief Executive Officer Charlie Scharf said in the statement, referring to an asset cap imposed by the Federal Reserve that was lifted in June.

headline: Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) Misses Q4 CY2025 Revenue Estimates
summary: Financial services giant Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) fell short of the markets revenue expectations in Q4 CY2025 as sales rose 4.1% year on year to $21.29 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $1.76 per share was 4.4% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

content.title: Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) Misses Q4 CY2025 Revenue Estimates
content.summary: Financial services giant Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) fell short of the markets revenue expectations in Q4 CY2025 as sales rose 4.1% year on year to $21.29 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $1.76 per share was 4.4% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Wells Fargo Fourth-Quarter Profit Rises 6%
summary: Noninterest income also rose.  Wells said it expected net-interest income to rise in 2026, boosted in part by balance sheet growth and assuming the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates two to three times.  It was the second full quarter Wells was free from the asset cap that the Federal Reserve put in place in 2018 as a punishment for its fake-account scandal.

content.title: Wells Fargo Fourth-Quarter Profit Rises 6%
content.summary: Noninterest income also rose. It was the second full quarter Wells was free from the asset cap that the Federal Reserve put in place in 2018 as a punishment for its fake-account scandal.

headline: Wells Fargo Reports Fourth Quarter 2025 Financial Results
summary: SAN FRANCISCO, January 14, 2026--Wells Fargo & Company (NYSE: WFC) has released its fourth quarter 2025 financial results. The financial results are available online at https://www.wellsfargo.com/about/investor-relations/quarterly-earnings/ and on a Form 8-K filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on Jan. 14, 2026, and available on the SEC’s website at https://www.sec.gov.

headline: Wells Fargo: Q4 Earnings Snapshot
summary: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC) on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $5.36 billion. The San Francisco-based company said it had earnings of $1.62 per share. Earnings, adjusted for severance costs, came to $1.76 per share.

content.title: Wells Fargo: Q4 Earnings Snapshot
content.summary: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC) on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $5.36 billion. The San Francisco-based company said it had earnings of $1.62 per share. Earnings, adjusted for severance costs, came to $1.76 per share.

headline: Bull Market for Stocks Lifts Wells Fargo’s Wealth Unit
summary: Wells Fargo’s wealth management unit reported higher net income for the fourth quarter and an increase in client assets, which received a boost from the current bull market.  Net income for the wealth unit came in at $656 million, a 29% year- over-year increase.  Wells Fargo said total client assets for the wealth unit were $2.5 trillion at the end of the quarter, an increase of 9% from the same period a year ago.

content.title: Bull Market for Stocks Lifts Wells Fargo’s Wealth Unit
content.summary: Wells Fargo’s wealth management unit reported higher net income for the fourth quarter and an increase in client assets, which received a boost from the current bull market.  Net income for the wealth unit came in at $656 million, a 29% year- over-year increase.  Wells Fargo said total client assets for the wealth unit were $2.5 trillion at the end of the quarter, an increase of 9% from the same period a year ago.

headline: Wells Fargo Raises Provision for Credit Losses to More Than $1 Billion
summary: Wells Fargo set aside just over $1 billion in the fourth quarter in case customers fall behind on their loans, an increase from the third quarter’s $681 million provision for credit losses. For the fourth quarter of 2024, Wells Fargo reported $1.

content.summary: Wells Fargo set aside just over $1 billion in the fourth quarter in case customers fall behind on their loans, an increase from the third quarter’s $681 million provision for credit losses. For the fourth quarter of 2024, Wells Fargo reported $1.

headline: Wells Fargo Expects Higher Net Interest Income in 2026
summary: Wells Fargo said it expects net interest income to rise to about $50 billion in 2026 from approximately $47.5 billion in 2025 thanks to a growing balance sheet, changes in loan and deposit mix, and repricing of fixed assets.  Net interest income, a key metric for banks, is the difference between what a bank earns on interest-bearing assets and pays in interest on customer deposits.  Wells Fargo’s projection assumes that there will only be two to three cuts in the fed funds rate and the 10-year Treasury will remain relatively stable in 2026, according to a company earnings presentation.

content.title: Wells Fargo Expects Higher Net Interest Income in 2026
content.summary: Wells Fargo said it expects net interest income to rise to about $50 billion in 2026 from approximately $47.5 billion in 2025 thanks to a growing balance sheet, changes in loan and deposit mix, and repricing of fixed assets.  Net interest income, a key metric for banks, is the difference between what a bank earns on interest-bearing assets and pays in interest on customer deposits.  Wells Fargo’s projection assumes that there will only be two to three cuts in the fed funds rate and the 10-year Treasury will remain relatively stable in 2026, according to a company earnings presentation.

headline: Wells Fargo Shares Slump Most in Six Months After Earnings Miss
summary: Shares of the company fell by the most in six months.  Expenses were $13.7 billion, compared with the $13.6 billion predicted by analysts in a Bloomberg survey, according to a statement Wednesday.  “We have built a strong foundation and have made great progress in improving growth and returns, though we have operated with significant constraints,” Chief Executive Officer Charlie Scharf said in the statement, referring to an asset cap imposed by the Federal Reserve that was lifted in June.

content.title: Wells Fargo Shares Slump Most in Six Months After Earnings Miss
content.summary: Shares of the company fell by the most in six months.  Expenses were $13.7 billion, compared with the $13.6 billion predicted by analysts in a Bloomberg survey, according to a statement Wednesday.  “We have built a strong foundation and have made great progress in improving growth and returns, though we have operated with significant constraints,” Chief Executive Officer Charlie Scharf said in the statement, referring to an asset cap imposed by the Federal Reserve that was lifted in June.

headline: Banks’ Wealth Units Are Riding High
summary: A bull market for stocks is boosting assets and profits at the wealth management business units of Wells Fargo, Citigroup, and Bank of America, which owns Merrill.  Wells Fargo said quarterly net income for its wealth unit came in at $656 million, a 29% year-over-year increase.  Total client assets were $2.5 trillion at the end of the quarter, an increase of 9% from the same period a year ago.

content.title: Banks’ Wealth Units Are Riding High
content.summary: A bull market for stocks is boosting assets and profits at the wealth management business units of Wells Fargo, Citigroup, and Bank of America, which owns Merrill.  Wells Fargo said quarterly net income for its wealth unit came in at $656 million, a 29% year-over-year increase.  Total client assets were $2.5 trillion at the end of the quarter, an increase of 9% from the same period a year ago.

headline: Trump’s Proposed Cap on Card Rates Could Crimp Access to Credit, Says Wells Fargo
summary: Wells Fargo Chief Financial Officer Mike Santomassimo said President Donald Trump’s proposed cap on credit card rates could hurt economic growth and hinder Americans’ ability to access credit, warning of “a negative impact on credit availability.”  The president suggested capping credit card rates at 10% for one year, a move to address voter complaints about the cost of living.  The proposal has gotten a cool reception from Wall Street, and analysts have said that if it takes effect it would force banks to drop lower-income credit card customers.

content.title: Trump’s Proposed Cap on Card Rates Could Crimp Access to Credit, Says Wells Fargo
content.summary: Wells Fargo Chief Financial Officer Mike Santomassimo said President Donald Trump’s proposed cap on credit card rates could hurt economic growth and hinder Americans’ ability to access credit, warning of “a negative impact on credit availability.”  The president suggested capping credit card rates at 10% for one year, a move to address voter complaints about the cost of living.  The proposal has gotten a cool reception from Wall Street, and analysts have said that if it takes effect it would force banks to drop lower-income credit card customers.

headline: Big Bank earnings: Takeaways from Q4 results
summary: It's a busy day for bank stocks as Wells Fargo (WFC), Citigroup (C), and Bank of America (BAC) released their fourth quarter earnings results on Wednesday. B. Riley Wealth chief market strategist Art Hogan and Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Ines Ferré react to this morning's bank earnings, including the figures on investment banking and how executives are reacting to President Trump's suggested 10% cap on credit card rates. headline: Bank earnings, commodities gains, retail sales & PPI: 3 Things
summary: Big Bank stocks Wells Fargo (WFC), Citigroup (C), and Bank of America (BAC) released their fourth quarter earnings results this morning. US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) fall in Wednesday's pre-market trading, while oil prices (CL=F, BZ=F) continue to tick back up and gold (GC=F) and silver (SI=F) climb to new record highs. US retail sales topped expectations for November, while December's Producer Price Index (PPI) inflation reading came out hotter than expected. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Wells Fargo Shares Fall Most in Six Months After Profit Miss
summary: Shares of the company fell by the most in six months.  Expenses were $13.7 billion, compared with the $13.6 billion predicted by analysts in a Bloomberg survey, according to a statement Wednesday.  “We have built a strong foundation and have made great progress in improving growth and returns, though we have operated with significant constraints,” Chief Executive Officer Charlie Scharf said in the statement, referring to an asset cap imposed by the Federal Reserve that was lifted in June.

content.title: Wells Fargo Shares Fall Most in Six Months After Profit Miss
content.summary: Shares of the company fell by the most in six months.  Expenses were $13.7 billion, compared with the $13.6 billion predicted by analysts in a Bloomberg survey, according to a statement Wednesday.  “We have built a strong foundation and have made great progress in improving growth and returns, though we have operated with significant constraints,” Chief Executive Officer Charlie Scharf said in the statement, referring to an asset cap imposed by the Federal Reserve that was lifted in June.

headline: Stock Market Today: Dow Improves Slightly While AppLovin Makes Giant Move (Live Coverage)
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and the other major stock indexes trimmed larger losses Wednesday afternoon as Wall Street remained skittish over new inflation data.  Among the losers was Nvidia as well as a number of banks after their earnings results.  Meanwhile, AppLovin sank on the stock market today.

headline: S&P 500 Slips After Bank Earnings
summary: STOCKS  Stocks slipped early Wednesday, after more bank earnings rolled in.  Bank of America posted a 12% rise in quarterly profit, boosted by consumer spending. But its stock dropped, as did shares in Wells Fargo which posted disappointing net income per share.

content.title: S&P 500 Slips After Bank Earnings
content.summary: STOCKS  Stocks slipped early Wednesday, after more bank earnings rolled in.  Bank of America posted a 12% rise in quarterly profit, boosted by consumer spending. But its stock dropped, as did shares in Wells Fargo which posted disappointing net income per share.
